responses_baseline_two: Incorrect: Sign up now Thought: The link text "Sign up now" does not meet WCAG 2.0 AAA enhanced contrast ratio requirements. The text is not distinguishable from its background color. Suggested change: Use the text "Join us today" or another similar phrase as the link text to improve contrast between the text and background color. The link can still be styled with the appropriate colors to make it visible and distinguishable from the background. The link class "btn" can be used with the appropriate CSS styles to make it appear as a button element.

responses_baseline_two:
The website you are currently operating is <https://www.mirror.co.uk>. The error you have mentioned is "color-contrast-enhanced", which suggests that there may be an issue with ensuring that the contrast between the foreground and background colors meets the WCAG 2.1 AAA enhanced contrast ratio standards.

To fix this, we would suggest the following approach:

1. Ensure that the text color has sufficient contrast with the background color, as per the WCAG 2.1 AAA enhanced contrast ratio standards. You can use a color contrast checker tool to verify the contrast ratio.
2. If the contrast ratio is not sufficient, consider using a color with higher contrast, or adjusting the text size or spacing to improve readability.
3. Ensure that the color scheme is accessible and does not create visual barriers, such as color-blindness or other sensory limitations.
4. Test the website with assistive technologies like screen readers, keyboard-only navigation, and color-blindness simulators to ensure that it meets accessibility standards.

We hope this helps you improve the accessibility of your website and provide a better user experience for all visitors.

responses_baseline_two:

To fix accessibility issues on a website, we need to consider the following points:

### Color Contrast Enhanced

Ensure that there is sufficient contrast between foreground and background colors to make text and other elements on the website easily readable. You can do this by using a color contrast checker tool, which will help you determine the contrast ratio between different colors and ensure that it meets WCAG 2.1 standards.

### Text-to-Speech

Add a text-to-speech feature that can convert written text into spoken word. This feature can be helpful for people with visual impairments who may have difficulty reading the content on your website.

### Screen Reader Compatibility

Make sure that the website is compatible with screen readers like JAWS, NVDA, VoiceOver, and others. This means that all the elements on the website should be labeled correctly, so users with disabilities can navigate it using the screen reader.

### Alternative Text

Provide alternative text for all images, videos, and graphics on the website. This will allow users with visual impairments to understand the content of the media.

### Keyboard Navigability

Ensure that the website is completely navigable using a keyboard. Users with disabilities may have difficulty using a mouse and rely on keyboard navigation to navigate the website.

### Focus Indicators

Provide focus indicators on the website to help users with disabilities understand which element they are currently interacting with. This can be done by using a different color or style for the focused element.

### ARIA Attributes

Add ARIA attributes to the HTML elements on the website to provide additional information to assistive technologies like screen readers.

### Consistent Navigation

Provide a consistent navigation structure that is easy to use and understand for all users, regardless of their abilities.

### Clear Content

Make sure that the content on the website is clear, concise, and easy to read. Use plain language and avoid using jargon, slang, or other words that may be difficult for users with cognitive disabilities to understand.

### Responsive Design

Make sure that the website is designed to be responsive and accessible on all devices, including mobile phones, tablets, and desktops.

### Regular Testing

Regularly test the website for accessibility issues to ensure that it remains accessible and usable for all users, including those with disabilities.

responses_baseline_two:
The website is operating on Coursera, an online learning platform that allows users to access a wide range of courses and degrees from universities and institutions across the world. Coursera's color contrast accessibility issue is that it does not meet WCAG 2.1 AAA enhanced contrast ratio thresholds.

To improve the color contrast accessibility of Coursera, it is recommended to ensure that the contrast ratio between the text and the background meets the WCAG 2.1 AAA enhanced contrast ratio thresholds. This can be achieved by using a color contrast checker tool, such as WAVE or Lighthouse, to identify and fix any issues. Additionally, it may be helpful to involve accessibility experts in the design and development process to ensure that the website is accessible to all users.

To fix this, the website can increase the contrast of the colors used in the links to make them more visible for users with low vision. The website can also provide text alternatives for images and icons to make them more accessible for users who are visually impaired.

responses_baseline_two:
This is a list of accessibility issues that need to be fixed for the website <https://www.scmp.com/>.

1. Insufficient color contrast: The website does not meet the minimum color contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for larger text. This makes it difficult for users with visual impairments to read the content.
2. Lack of alt text for images: Many images on the website do not have alt text, which means that users who are blind or have low vision cannot understand the meaning of the image.
3. Poor keyboard navigation: Keyboard navigation is not intuitive on the website, making it difficult for users who cannot use a mouse to navigate and access content.
4. Inadequate headings hierarchy: The website's headings hierarchy is not clear, making it difficult for users to understand the structure of the content and navigate to relevant sections.
5. Unclear link text: Many links on the website have unclear text, making it difficult for users to understand the destination of the click.
6. Lack of ARIA landmarks: The website does not use ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) landmarks, which are essential for users with screen readers to understand the structure of the content and navigate to relevant sections.
7. Poor form labeling: Forms on the website do not have clear labels, making it difficult for users to understand the purpose of each input field and provide correct information.
8. Unclear date and time format: The website uses different date and time formats, making it difficult for users to understand the information and make sense of it.
9. Inadequate captioning and transcription: Videos on the website do not have captions or transcriptions, making it difficult for users who are deaf or hard of hearing to access the content.
10. Lack of text alternatives for multimedia content: The website does not provide text alternatives for multimedia content, such as audio descriptions for videos or captions for images, making it difficult for users who are blind or have low vision to access the content.

These issues can be addressed by implementing accessible design principles, such as increasing color contrast, providing alt text for images, improving keyboard navigation, clarifying headings hierarchy, using clear link text, using ARIA landmarks, providing clear form labels, using consistent date and time formats, providing captions and transcriptions, and providing text alternatives for multimedia content.

responses_baseline_two:
Before suggesting a corrected version, I would like to provide some context and explanation for the suggested change. The error message you provided indicates that the website is not meeting the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2 AAA contrast ratio thresholds. This means that some of the text on the website may be difficult for users with low vision or color blindness to read due to the low contrast between the text and its background. To address this issue, the suggested change is to ensure that the contrast between foreground and background colors meets the enhanced contrast ratio thresholds, which are a bit higher than the standard AAA threshold. This is because the enhanced contrast ratio thresholds are designed to provide a better user experience for users with low vision or color blindness. Incorporating the suggested change would make the website more accessible for a wider range of users, including those with visual impairments. Here is a corrected version of the code: Incorrect:

responses_baseline_two:
The website appears to have several accessibility issues that need to be addressed. Here are some of the specific issues that were identified:

* Color-contrast-enhanced: The contrast between foreground and background colors may not meet WCAG 2 AAA enhanced contrast ratio thresholds.
* Heading structure: Some headings on the website may not have clear and consistent heading structure, making it difficult for users with screen readers to navigate the content.
* Keyboard navigation: Some parts of the website may not be fully navigable using only a keyboard, making it difficult for users with motor disabilities to access all of the content.
* Text alternatives: Some images on the website may not have clear and descriptive alternative text, making it difficult for users with visual impairments to understand the context of the images.
* Descriptive link text: Some links on the website may have generic or uninformative text, making it difficult for users to understand the purpose of the links and where they will lead.

To address these issues, the website may need to undergo an accessibility audit and make significant changes to the code and layout of the site. This process can be time-consuming and require the involvement of accessibility experts. However, ensuring that the website is accessible to all users is an important step in promoting equality and inclusion.

responses_baseline_two:
Before I suggest any changes to the provided website, I would like to clarify that the error message provided indicates an issue with the contrast ratio between the foreground and background colors used on the website. This issue can make the website difficult to read for individuals with visual impairments or those who have difficulty distinguishing between colors. To ensure that the website meets the WCAG 2.1 contrast ratio thresholds, it is important to use colors with a sufficient level of contrast between them.

With that in mind, I would suggest the following fixes to the provided website:

1. Increase the contrast between text and background colors: To ensure that the text is easily legible on the background, you can increase the contrast between them. One way to do this is by using a dark font color on a lighter background color or vice versa.
2. Use a color scheme that meets WCAG contrast ratio guidelines: You can use a color scheme that meets the WCAG 2.1 contrast ratio guidelines to ensure that the website is accessible to everyone. The guidelines recommend a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text.
3. Use high-contrast colors for buttons and links: It is important to use high-contrast colors for buttons and links to ensure that users can easily identify and click on them. You can use bright colors such as red or blue for the text and a dark background color to create a clear contrast.
4. Test the website for accessibility: Once you have made the necessary changes to the website, it is important to test it for accessibility to ensure that it meets WCAG 2.1 guidelines. You can use automated testing tools such as WAVE or manually test the website using a screen reader to identify any accessibility issues.

responses_baseline_two:
The issue with the provided code is that it does not properly label an element with an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute. Specifically, the element `
` does not have any aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute, so it is not accessible to users with visual impairments who rely on screen readers to navigate the website. To fix this issue, we need to add an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute to this element. A possible fix for this issue would be to add an aria-label attribute to the element, like this: ```
``` This will provide a text description of the element, which can be read by screen readers to help users understand what the element is. Alternatively, we could use an aria-labelledby attribute and add a label element with a for attribute that references the id of the element, like this: ```
``` This will associate the label with the element using its id, and allow screen readers to read the label as a description of the element. In general, it is important to ensure that all elements on a website have proper accessibility labels to help users with disabilities understand the content and navigate the website.

Educational games keep students actively involved, making learning more enjoyable and reducing passive absorption of information.

Add an aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute to the element that should be labeled as a region. The aria-label should provide a brief description of the element, while aria-labelledby should reference an ID or class that is used elsewhere in the document to provide further information about the region. It is also important to ensure that the region is properly scoped to the appropriate parent element, so that it does not overlap with other regions in the document. I hope this helps! responses_baseline_two:
Before suggesting a change, let's consider the context of the website and the purpose of the headings. It appears that the website provides resources and support related to data visualization, and the headings are used to organize the content.

Based on this information, it's important to maintain the logical order of the headings. For example, the resources and support section should be listed before the data visualization section, and the link list heading should be listed after both of these sections.

Considering these points, the suggested change would be:

Incorrect:

* <c4d-content-item-heading role="heading" aria-level="4" data-autoid="c4d--content-item__heading" slot="heading">Resources and support</c4d-content-item-heading>
<c4d-content-item-heading role="heading" aria-level="4" data-autoid="c4d--content-item__heading" slot="heading">Data visualization</c4d-content-item-heading>
<c4d-link-list-heading role="heading" aria-level="4" slot="heading" data-autoid="c4d--link-list-heading">More ways to explore</c4d-link-list-heading>

Corrected:

* <c4d-content-item-heading role="heading" aria-level="4" data-autoid="c4d--content-item__heading" slot="heading">Resources and support</c4d-content-item-heading>

Before providing the fixed version, I would like to clarify that the provided description is a bit unclear. It suggests that the audio should not autoplay for more than 3 seconds, but it does not specify if the audio should stop or continue to play after the 3 seconds or if it should be completely muted. Therefore, I suggest a more specific change based on the context and purpose of the audio.

Here's a suggestion for a fixed version based on the current implementation of the video element:

<video controls>
<source src="/test-assets/rabbit-video/video.mp4" type="video/mp4"
/>
<source src="/test-assets/rabbit-video/video.webm" type="video/webm" />
</video>

The `controls` attribute ensures that users have control over the playback of the video, allowing them to pause, play, or mute the audio if necessary. This meets the requirement of the "no-autoplay-audio" rule, as the audio will continue to play until the user interacts with the controls.

description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
affectedHTMLElement(s): <div id="universal-search-container" role="combobox" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-owns="universal-search-menu" class="searchContainer">
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.plex.tv/
        Error: aria-required-attr
        Description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
        Suggested change: ARIA role missing required attribute.
        Incorrect: <div id="universal-search-container" role="combobox" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-owns="universal-search-menu" class="searchContainer">
responses_baseline_two:
Search
The suggested change is to add an aria-label attribute to the search input. The ARIA role of "combobox" already implies that the element can be expanded and has a list of options, but it doesn't give any information about what the element actually does. The aria-label attribute provides a more specific and meaningful description of the element, which is important for users with visual impairments who rely on screen readers to navigate the web.

description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element
affectedHTMLElement(s): <input type="checkbox" id="vector-main-menu-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-main-menu-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Main menu">, <input type="checkbox" id="vector-user-links-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-user-links-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Personal tools">, <input type="checkbox" id="vector-page-tools-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-page-tools-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Tools">, <input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 16 languages">
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://en.wikiversity.org
        Error: aria-allowed-role
        Description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element
        Suggested change: An ARIA role is used that is not allowed for the element.
        Incorrect: <input type="checkbox" id="vector-main-menu-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-main-menu-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Main menu">, <input type="checkbox" id="vector-user-links-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-user-links-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Personal tools">, <input type="checkbox" id="vector-page-tools-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-page-tools-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox " aria-label="Tools">, <input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 16 languages">
responses_baseline_two:
Incorrect: 
```php
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-main-menu-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-main-menu-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Main menu">,
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-user-links-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-user-links-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Personal tools">,
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-page-tools-dropdown-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-page-tools-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Tools">,
<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 16 languages">
```
The ARIA roles used for the checkboxes are incorrect. Instead of using "button", the appropriate role for a checkbox should be "checkbox".

Corrected:
```php
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-main-menu-dropdown-checkbox" role="checkbox" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-main-menu-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Main menu">,
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-user-links-dropdown-checkbox" role="checkbox" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-user-links-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Personal tools">,
<input type="checkbox" id="vector-page-tools-dropdown-checkbox" role="checkbox" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-vector-page-tools-dropdown" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox" aria-label="Tools">,
<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="checkbox" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 16 languages">
``` 
The ARIA role for each checkbox has been changed to "checkbox", which is the appropriate role for this element type.

description: Ensures tabindex attribute values are not greater than 0
affectedHTMLElement(s): <input required="" type="email" placeholder="Your E-mail" "="" name="email" value="" tabindex="1">, <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Tell me more!" "="" tabindex="2">
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.readtheory.org
        Error: tabindex
        Description: Ensures tabindex attribute values are not greater than 0
        Suggested change: Tabindex value is either invalid or not used correctly.
        Incorrect: <input required="" type="email" placeholder="Your E-mail" "="" name="email" value="" tabindex="1">, <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Tell me more!" "="" tabindex="2">
responses_baseline_two:
Incorrect: <input required="" type="email" placeholder="Your E-mail" "="" name="email" value="" tabindex="1">, <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Tell me more!" "="" tabindex="2">
        Thought: Because it is not recommended to set tabindex values manually, and it can cause issues with the user experience. Instead, we can use the default values for the tabindex attribute based on the type of element. For input elements with the "required" attribute, the tabindex value should be set to 1 to allow the user to navigate through the form. And for submit elements, the tabindex value should be set to -1 to prevent navigation from jumping to the next form element when the user clicks the submit button.
        Correct: <input required="" type="email" placeholder="Your E-mail" "="" name="email" value="" tabindex="1">, <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Tell me more!" "="" tabindex="-1">

Therefore, I would not recommend making any changes to the current <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=2.0"> tag on the website as it is already compliant and correctly scaled for different devices.

The Accessibility Conformance Testing (ACT) Rules Format 1.0 defines a format for writing accessibility test rules. These test rules can be used for developing automated testing tools and manual testing methodologies. It provides a common format that allows any party involved in accessibility testing to document and share their testing procedures in a robust and understandable manner. This enables transparency and harmonization of testing methods, including methods implemented by accessibility test tools.

<form>

  <label for="submit">Submit</label>

</form>

<label for="submit-search">Search</label>
<input aria-labelledby="search" id="search" name="search" type="text"/>
<button id="submit-search" type="submit">Search</button>
```
This way, the label and the element are related, making it easier for screen reader users to understand what's happening on the page.

Mental Health Matters

Promoting awareness, reducing stigma, and encouraging self-care

Importance Self-Care Tips Resources

The Importance of Mental Health

Mental health is vital to overall well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act in our daily lives. Recognizing its importance helps reduce stigma and promotes a supportive community.

Self-Care Tips

Taking care of your mental health is essential. Here are a few tips:

  • Practice mindfulness or meditation
  • Stay physically active
  • Maintain a balanced diet
  • Connect with loved ones
  • Seek professional help when needed

Helpful Resources

If you're struggling with your mental health, don't hesitate to reach out for help. Here are some trusted resources:

  • National Mental Health Hotline
  • Mindfulness and Meditation Apps
  • Support Groups in Your Area

© 2025 Mental Health Awareness | Contact Us
